title: DataSnipper CEO: Europe doesnâ€™t have to follow the Silicon Valley playbook
description: For decades, European tech insiders have looked across the Atlantic with a mix of admiration and frustration. Casting envious eyes on the deep-pocketed VCs, an enormous consumer market, and a pipeline of elite talent,Â they often view the US as a promised land for business growth. The sentiment fuels calls for Europe to replicate Silicon Valleyâ€™s model. But Vidya Peters, CEO of Dutch unicorn DataSnipper, argues this approach is flawed. Rather than merely mimicking US tech, she urges startups and scaleups to embrace Europeâ€™s strengths. A key one is sustainable, long-term growth. â€œFive years ago, it wasnâ€™t very fashionable to beâ€¦This story continues at The Next Web
author: Thomas Macaulay
excerpt: Vidya Peters, the CEO of DataSnipper and a speaker at TNW Conference 2025, wants European startups to embrace the continent's strengths.
text: For decades, European tech insiders have looked across the Atlantic with a mix of admiration and frustration. Casting envious eyes on the deep-pocketed VCs, an enormous consumer market, and a pipeline of elite talent,Â they often view the US as a promised land for business growth. The sentiment fuels calls for Europe to replicate Silicon Valleyâ€™s model. But Vidya Peters, CEO of Dutch unicorn DataSnipper, argues this approach is flawed. Rather than merely mimicking US tech, she urges startups and scaleups to embrace Europeâ€™s strengths. A key one is sustainable, long-term growth. â€œFive years ago, it wasnâ€™t very fashionable to be profitable,â€ Peters tells TNW. â€œBut I think this is where the European sensibility is a strength, because European companies have always taken this approach, and now itâ€™s hugely valued in the current economic climate.â€ The ğŸ’œ of EU techThe latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!This sharply contrasts with Silicon Valleyâ€™s growth-at-all-costs mentality. European businesses are already benefiting from this distinct approach. â€œWhen you watch some of these companies come out, they are much more durable in their growth and competitive advantage,â€ Peters says. DataSnipper is a prime example. The company was profitable early on, scaled rapidly, and recently hit a $1bn valuation. Ahead of her headline talk at TNW Conference in June, Peters shared a few secrets behind the companyâ€™s success. One is based on another European trademark: data protection. Privacy and security are integral features of DataSnipperâ€™s core product, an AI-powered platform that automates repetitive finance and audit procedures.Â  Â â€œItâ€™s been super important to our customers that weâ€™re not training on their documents and data â€” and thatâ€™s been a central piece of how we built our AI products,â€ Peters says. â€œWe review and look at their data to provide insights, but that data is theirs.â€ The company must also abide by the EUâ€™s stringent data laws. Critics argue that these rules stifle innovation, but Peters points to the advantages. Â â€œEurope really has the opportunity to lead in this space by balancing innovation with customer data protection,â€ she says. By embedding safety and transparency into AI, she continues, startups and scaleups can carve out a competitive edge over US rivals. â€œDoing it from a base of trust can help European companies win customers in a different way than their American counterparts can.â€ DataSnipper also has roots in another European hallmark: a bar in Amsterdam.Â  From Amsterdam to the world In 2017,Â Maarten Alblas and Jonas RuyterÂ were having a beer. Joining them was a friend who worked in auditing for KPMG. He faced a common affliction in his profession: an enormous spreadsheet that required painstaking scrutiny. He had to search through the document for invoices, bank statements, and receipts â€” all the while cross-checking the data.Â  Alblas and Ruyter believed software could ease his suffering. They settled on a solution: an intelligent automation platform that would dramatically increase the quality and efficiency of common audit procedures. The idea led to the founding of DataSnipper. Their software proved a hit with auditors. Soon, their user base had spread from the Netherlands to the UK and Germany. After finding success in Europe, they targeted new markets beyond the continent. To further fuel the growth, the company appointed Vidya Peters as CEO in 2023. She joined with expertise honed in Silicon Valley, most recently as Chief Marketing Officer of MuleSoft. During her time at the software giant, the company went public on the NYSE before being acquired by Salesforce for $6.5bn.Â  She later gained extensive experience of Europeâ€™s tech landscape. In 2019, she served as Chief Operating Officer of Marqeta, a payment processing firm. Again, she helped her company go public. In 2022, Marqeta made its market debut on the Nasdaq. The company ended the day with a market cap of over $16bn. At DataSnipper, she set her sights on accelerating growth and global expansion. The strategy has reaped rewards. In 2024, Deloitte named DataSnipper the fastest-growing tech company in the Netherlands for the second year in a row. Last month, the business reached the coveted unicorn status after raising $100mn at a $1bn valuation. Over 500,000 audit and finance professionals across more than 125 countries now use the software. As DataSnipper scaled, the company benefited from another European advantage: access to international talent.Â  DataSnipperâ€™s talent pipeline â€œPeople undervalue the ability to hire from across the world here,â€ says Peters. DataSnipper has directly benefited from this access. From the Netherlands, the company can hire global talent on a visa with greater ease than in the US. Peters describes this as â€œa secret weaponâ€ for European startups and scaleups. â€œIt is much easier to do so with the visa opportunities that you have in Europe, the ability to issue work visas is significantly easier in Europe than it is in the US.â€ A diverse range of people now work for DataSnipper. In the companyâ€™s Amsterdam headquarters, 70% of employees are from outside the Netherlands. â€œThatâ€™s incredibly valuable because we have every language that you could possibly want to sell in Europe, and you can attract them right here to Amsterdam,â€ says Peters. DataSnipperâ€™s global outlook has been instrumental in its expansion. After establishing itself in Europe, DataSnipper opened offices in New York, Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, and Mexico City. Despite its global expansion, DataSnipper remains firmly rooted in the Netherlands. One of the countryâ€™s many attractions is a simple matter of time. â€œPeople forget that America is not the heart of the world,â€ says Peters. â€œYou can wake up in Europe and sell to Asia Pacific. And after your lunch, you can sell to the US.â€ Europeâ€™s pros and cons Despite the advantages of life in Europe, startups here still face substantial challenges. One is the diverging regulations, tax laws, and banking systems, which present roadblocks to growth across the continent. â€œWeâ€™re not taking full advantage of being part of one European Union and allowing companies to expand within the continent,â€ Peters says. â€œIt would be tremendously beneficial if we could open locations within Europe, just like you would in the US, in a different state.â€ Funding is another hurdle. European VCs tend to be more risk-averse, making capital harder to secure. â€œWe had conversations with probably every major venture capital firm in the US â€” they were pounding on our door,â€ says Peters. â€œYet the European VCs were not reaching out.â€ For DataSnipper, that wasnâ€™t a big problem. The US firms alone had produced anÂ oversubscribed round. Nonetheless, Peters was surprised: where were the European investors? With curious timing, they started reaching out after the funding was announced. â€œWas it the risk appetite?â€ Peters wonders. â€œWhat was it that made them a little bit more cautious?â€ These are common questions in European tech. But startups and scaleups donâ€™t need to wait for the answers. Peters advises them to think beyond borders. â€œDonâ€™t be limited to the country you are in or to Europe,â€ she says. â€œReach out to VCs all over the world.â€ When that happens, Peters hopes that Europeâ€™s investment landscape will shift to a braver funding model. But even if it doesnâ€™t, companies across the continent can forge their own paths to success. Vidya Peters will provide further insights atÂ TNW Conference, which takes place on June 19-20 in Amsterdam. Tickets for the event areÂ now on sale. To get 30% off, use the code TNWXMEDIA2025 at the check-out.
html:
For decades, European tech insiders have looked across the Atlantic with a mix of admiration and frustration. Casting envious eyes on the deep-pocketed VCs, an enormous consumer market, and a pipeline of elite talent,Â they often view the US as a promised land for business growth.

The sentiment fuels calls for Europe to replicate Silicon Valleyâ€™s model. But Vidya Peters, CEO of Dutch unicorn DataSnipper, argues this approach is flawed.

Rather than merely mimicking US tech, she urges startups and scaleups to embrace Europeâ€™s strengths. A key one is sustainable, long-term growth.

â€œFive years ago, it wasnâ€™t very fashionable to be profitable,â€ Peters tells TNW. â€œBut I think this is where the European sensibility is a strength, because European companies have always taken this approach, and now itâ€™s hugely valued in the current economic climate.â€

The ğŸ’œ of EU tech

The latest rumblings from the EU tech scene, a story from our wise ol' founder Boris, and some questionable AI art. It's free, every week, in your inbox. Sign up now!

This sharply contrasts with Silicon Valleyâ€™s growth-at-all-costs mentality. European businesses are already benefiting from this distinct approach. â€œWhen you watch some of these companies come out, they are much more durable in their growth and competitive advantage,â€ Peters says.

DataSnipper is a prime example. The company was profitable early on, scaled rapidly, and recently hit a $1bn valuation. Ahead of her headline talk at TNW Conference in June, Peters shared a few secrets behind the companyâ€™s success.

One is based on another European trademark: data protection. Privacy and security are integral features of DataSnipperâ€™s core product, an AI-powered platform that automates repetitive finance and audit procedures.Â 

Â â€œItâ€™s been super important to our customers that weâ€™re not training on their documents and data â€” and thatâ€™s been a central piece of how we built our AI products,â€ Peters says. â€œWe review and look at their data to provide insights, but that data is theirs.â€

The company must also abide by the EUâ€™s stringent data laws. Critics argue that these rules stifle innovation, but Peters points to the advantages.

Â â€œEurope really has the opportunity to lead in this space by balancing innovation with customer data protection,â€ she says.

By embedding safety and transparency into AI, she continues, startups and scaleups can carve out a competitive edge over US rivals.

â€œDoing it from a base of trust can help European companies win customers in a different way than their American counterparts can.â€

DataSnipper also has roots in another European hallmark: a bar in Amsterdam.Â 

From Amsterdam to the world

In 2017,Â Maarten Alblas and Jonas RuyterÂ were having a beer. Joining them was a friend who worked in auditing for KPMG. He faced a common affliction in his profession: an enormous spreadsheet that required painstaking scrutiny. He had to search through the document for invoices, bank statements, and receipts â€” all the while cross-checking the data.Â 

Alblas and Ruyter believed software could ease his suffering. They settled on a solution: an intelligent automation platform that would dramatically increase the quality and efficiency of common audit procedures. The idea led to the founding of DataSnipper.

Their software proved a hit with auditors. Soon, their user base had spread from the Netherlands to the UK and Germany. After finding success in Europe, they targeted new markets beyond the continent.

To further fuel the growth, the company appointed Vidya Peters as CEO in 2023. She joined with expertise honed in Silicon Valley, most recently as Chief Marketing Officer of MuleSoft. During her time at the software giant, the company went public on the NYSE before being acquired by Salesforce for $6.5bn.Â 

She later gained extensive experience of Europeâ€™s tech landscape. In 2019, she served as Chief Operating Officer of Marqeta, a payment processing firm. Again, she helped her company go public. In 2022, Marqeta made its market debut on the Nasdaq. The company ended the day with a market cap of over $16bn.

At DataSnipper, she set her sights on accelerating growth and global expansion.

The strategy has reaped rewards. In 2024, Deloitte named DataSnipper the fastest-growing tech company in the Netherlands for the second year in a row. Last month, the business reached the coveted unicorn status after raising $100mn at a $1bn valuation. Over 500,000 audit and finance professionals across more than 125 countries now use the software.

As DataSnipper scaled, the company benefited from another European advantage: access to international talent.Â 

DataSnipperâ€™s talent pipeline

â€œPeople undervalue the ability to hire from across the world here,â€ says Peters.

DataSnipper has directly benefited from this access. From the Netherlands, the company can hire global talent on a visa with greater ease than in the US. Peters describes this as â€œa secret weaponâ€ for European startups and scaleups.

â€œIt is much easier to do so with the visa opportunities that you have in Europe, the ability to issue work visas is significantly easier in Europe than it is in the US.â€

A diverse range of people now work for DataSnipper. In the companyâ€™s Amsterdam headquarters, 70% of employees are from outside the Netherlands.

â€œThatâ€™s incredibly valuable because we have every language that you could possibly want to sell in Europe, and you can attract them right here to Amsterdam,â€ says Peters.

DataSnipperâ€™s global outlook has been instrumental in its expansion. After establishing itself in Europe, DataSnipper opened offices in New York, Tokyo, Kuala Lumpur, and Mexico City.

Despite its global expansion, DataSnipper remains firmly rooted in the Netherlands. One of the countryâ€™s many attractions is a simple matter of time.

â€œPeople forget that America is not the heart of the world,â€ says Peters. â€œYou can wake up in Europe and sell to Asia Pacific. And after your lunch, you can sell to the US.â€

Europeâ€™s pros and cons

Despite the advantages of life in Europe, startups here still face substantial challenges. One is the diverging regulations, tax laws, and banking systems, which present roadblocks to growth across the continent.

â€œWeâ€™re not taking full advantage of being part of one European Union and allowing companies to expand within the continent,â€ Peters says. â€œIt would be tremendously beneficial if we could open locations within Europe, just like you would in the US, in a different state.â€

Funding is another hurdle. European VCs tend to be more risk-averse, making capital harder to secure. â€œWe had conversations with probably every major venture capital firm in the US â€” they were pounding on our door,â€ says Peters. â€œYet the European VCs were not reaching out.â€

For DataSnipper, that wasnâ€™t a big problem. The US firms alone had produced anÂ oversubscribed round. Nonetheless, Peters was surprised: where were the European investors? With curious timing, they started reaching out after the funding was announced.

â€œWas it the risk appetite?â€ Peters wonders. â€œWhat was it that made them a little bit more cautious?â€

These are common questions in European tech. But startups and scaleups donâ€™t need to wait for the answers.

Peters advises them to think beyond borders. â€œDonâ€™t be limited to the country you are in or to Europe,â€ she says. â€œReach out to VCs all over the world.â€

When that happens, Peters hopes that Europeâ€™s investment landscape will shift to a braver funding model. But even if it doesnâ€™t, companies across the continent can forge their own paths to success.

Vidya Peters will provide further insights atÂ TNW Conference, which takes place on June 19-20 in Amsterdam. Tickets for the event areÂ now on sale. To get 30% off, use the code TNWXMEDIA2025 at the check-out.
